body:
On the superset 0.15.4 there was some internal error and it didn't returned any data for the query.
On the UI I have seen message **No data** available.
I can't say what was the issue internally because I am not a python dev and I don't have skills to debug python code.
Regarding superset version 0.15.3 - I didn't tried this version.
And regarding superset version 0.15.2 - it is not available in the PyPI repository.

@ridha shouldn't that now be implemented back into the master project? Should I implement that fix or tag this - sorry I'm not 100% familiar with how to proceed but seems obvious they should upgrade the pypi version right?

I found one way to fix this.
Apparently, the sqlalchemy only connect to the database that is defined as "Default database" on the user at SQL Server level.

Is there any other way to use a single user to connect to multiple databases ?
Ok, this should be fixed in 1.16.x

@kedare this seems very related to similar issues observed on Postgres/Redshift as these databases have an extra layer of namespacing. Postgres has multiple schemas per "database" and SQL Server has multiple "owners" I believe.

SQLAlchemy, as a common denominator API to interface with these databases has some limitations and doesn't offer the abstractions we need to deal with all this (afaik).

It seems like ideally we'd need the left panel navigator in SQL Lab to allow to navigate the full namespacing of each database engine, with the proper labels for the dropdowns. For this to work, we'd have to customize the code a bit. Luckily there's already a placeholder module to handle this abstraction (`db_engine_specs.py`). 

We need a comprehensive solution that will make it clear what the levels of namespacing are and related methods/endpoints to get lists of these objects.
Airbnb won't drive this at this moment, only enable people in the community to do so. Whatever solution gets put in place we should make sure that it works for all db engines.
it would help to have info about your backend and python version

What would be the best way to use it for a single schema ?

I could add the database, see the tables, but I can't run any query, I always get : (pymssql.OperationalError) (18456, b'DB-Lib error message 20018, severity 11:\nGeneral SQL Server error: Check messages from the SQL Server\nDB-Lib error message 20018, severity 14:\nGeneral SQL Server error: Check messages from the SQL Server\nDB-Lib error message 20002, severity 9:\nAdaptive Server connection failed (DBLive1:1433)\n')

And when checking SQL Server logs : Login failed for user 'app-superset'. Reason: Failed to open the explicitly specified database 'dbo'. [CLIENT: 10.0.0.xx]

It's trying to connect to the dbo database (That doesn't exists) instead of using the dbo schema. (I removed any explicit schema of the configuration)
Hmm... I tested more, when I empty the "schema" field on the SQL Lab, I don't get this error anymore, but then when the query finishes running, I get an "Unserializable object"
Hmm some tables work fine, some others not, maybe there are some datatype that can cause that ? I'll do more testing

Here's a hacky fix we just landed (not deployed) for postgres:
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/1789/files

You could try adding `mssql` where it says `redshift` and see if it allows you to move forward

Pandas is quite memory hungry. I can't load a sparse 1GB csv file on my 16GB system due to MemoryError.

Plot.ly offers a tutorial on how to convert a CSV to SQLite chunk by chunk to avoid eating all the memory. https://plot.ly/python/big-data-analytics-with-pandas-and-sqlite/.

It's probably useful for superset to use a similar conversion step so an arbitrarily sized csv can be converted.

If speed is an issue as pandas.read_csv is single-threaded, an alternative is `paratext` https://github.com/wiseio/paratext. the load_csv_to_pandas function is using all cores and is much faster than pandas.
It doesn't solve the whole memory issue though: while it's quite efficient while reading and processing the CSV, the last conversion to pandas dataframe will use as much memory as pandas alone.
this was because contribution was accidentally clicked, solved by uncheck the contribution box

This is fixed in 0.16.x! [soon to be release, maybe today!]

You can add utf8 file header manually, to tell software decode it with utf8
header = bytes(b'\xEF\xBB\xBF').decode('utf-8')
return Response(
                header+payload,
                status=200,
                headers=generate_download_headers("csv"),
                mimetype="application/csv")

Ok, done with this round of review, I'm not clear on why we needed striping before and not anymore, some for unquoting, why do we do it on SQLA side but not druid?
PR welcomed!

Thanks, I will take a look.

I have another issue related to MSSQL, I could do a SQL query that appears fine in the SQL Editior, I can see the result also :

```
select c.Name as country, count(*) as count from House as h
inner join Country as c on h.country_id = c.id
group by c.Name
order by count desc
```

But when I try to graph it (with Vizualize, with the default parameter), if I try to get a Pie Chart for example (Count of each group), I get an "error" (Just the red div) with just " 'country' " inside.


I did something similar with a MySQL datasource without any issue.

Do you have any idea of what could be the cause ?

python setup.py install

Hi Nishant,



On my POC environment,

Druid broker and coordinator configured properly on superset. as per troubleshooting  figure out broker node unable to resolve historical node ec2 private ip address than replaced private ip address with hostname. on broker node logs historical node still showing same errror. that time i suspect DNS issue may be causing this problem. for verification historical node private ip address mapped on broker node hosts file and restarted service on both node historical and broker node.


historical node

druid.host=historical (planning to use DNS name for all node through ansible)
druid.service=/druid/historical
druid.port=8083

Broker node
druid.host=ec2-xx-xx-xx-xxx.compute-1.amazonaws.com (EIP)
druid.service=druid/broker
druid.port=8082
druid.startup.logging.logProperties=true
druid.selectors.indexing.serviceName=druid:overlord
druid.selectors.coordinator.serviceName=druid:coordinator

/etc/hosts entry
10.x.x.10          historical


after adding  my issue resolved. now i am able to query all my data source. i am still working on scaling of my entire configuration through (terrform/ansible). thanks for your valuable responce.

Regards,
Laxman Singh

The SQL Editor should be autofilled with:
```
SELECT
    1 AS `COLUMN`
FROM ( SELECT 2 = 5 ) t
WHERE TRUE
```

instead it gets truncated to:

```
SELECT
    1 AS `COLUMN`
FROM ( SELECT 2 
```

Sounds reasonable, the FilterBox widget could make that optional with a checkbox control "Instataneous". If checked (default) same as current behavior, if unchecked, a new "Apply" button is exposed and needs to be clicked.

@kedare do you mind trying to add a line that says `limit_method = LimitMethod.FETCH_MANY`
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/superset/db_engine_specs.py#L337

The idea is that we want to limit the number of rows returned even when users query large tables. This line will change the approach from wrapping the user's SQL as a subquery to using the cursor's `fetchmany(LIMIT)` method instead. 

Let me know if it works and please send that in a PR if it does.

Please post the full backtrace, then please try yo upgrade pandas to the latest release and report back.
What's the problem you see of recreating a new engine each request?

It seems that every time you call create_engine there is an overhead tax of 2 SQL calls to check casting capabilities of your datasource. 2 calls for each request for each worker process per slice per page load can add up. SQLAlchemy also recommends creating once and reusing to get performance advantage out of connection pooling.
